title: How to Clean a Dyson Fan

parts.name: Cleaning the Outside of the Fan

steps.headline: Unplug the fan.
steps.description: Before cleaning your Dyson fan, make sure to unplug it. This prevents any risk of injury, and allows you to clean the fan thoroughly.

steps.headline: Wipe the inside of the fan with a moist cloth.
steps.description: Dyson fans do not have blades, which makes the cleaning process a lot easier. Use a moist cloth to wipe inside the circular surface of the fan in long, swift motions. This process probably won’t take you more than 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Use a wipe to clean the outermost surface of the fan.
steps.description: In addition to the fan’s inner portion, you should also clean the outside of the fan. You can use a wet paper towel or for this part of the cleaning process. Baby wipes also work for this part of the process.

steps.headline: Attach a tube or brush extension to your vacuum.
steps.description: Find the attachment tube on your vacuum that allows you to clean smaller areas. Depending on your vacuum, you may have different kinds of  attachments. Add a long, thin tube or the brush attachment to your vacuum before continuing. If you don’t think you have the right vacuum attachment, consider purchasing one from an online marketplace (i.e, Amazon, eBay).

steps.headline: Locate the back vents by searching for circular grooves.
steps.description: The location of the back vents may differ depending on your fan model. You can easily identify these vents by finding rows of circular grooves in a square pattern towards the bottom of your Dyson fan.

steps.headline: Vacuum the back vent of the fan.
steps.description: Turn on the vacuum and hold the tube or brush extension tightly in one hand. Using careful and methodical movements, clear the dust from the back vent of your Dyson fan. Ideally, you do not want to see any dust particles once you have finished vacuuming. If you don’t have a vacuum or vacuum extension, feel free to use a can of compressed air. You can purchase this at most office supply stores.

steps.headline: Brush off any remaining dust with a paper towel.
steps.description: Once you have finished vacuuming the back vents of the Dyson fan, examine the surface for any lingering dust or dirt. Using a dry paper towel or cloth, remove any excess dust with long, quick movements. Repeat this process if you still see a significant amount of dust.

parts.name: Wiping out the Inside of the Fan

steps.headline: Twist off the top part of the fan.
steps.description: Use one hand to hold the bottom portion of the fan in place, and use your other hand to twist off the top, circular portion. Twist in a counter-clockwise motion when working to separate the two pieces of the Dyson fan. Don’t be discouraged if you’re unable to remove the top part. Check your fan’s user manual for more specific instructions on how to disassemble it. There should be a visible line that separates the rounded portion of the fan from the rest of the machine.

steps.headline: Remove any dust from inside the fan with a wipe.
steps.description: While a Dyson fan does not have blades, there is a mechanical portion visible inside the fan after you’ve separated the two pieces. Use quick, delicate motions to lightly clean this inner portion with a damp cloth. You can use a can of compressed air instead of a damp cloth.

steps.headline: Clean out the top part of the fan with a moist wipe.
steps.description: Using both hands, hold the circular portion upright so that you can examine the inside for dust. Depending on how much dust you find, use a damp cloth to clean and remove any dirt particles from inside the fan. Use small, careful motions during the cleaning process when wiping any rounded edges of the inner fan. You can also use a baby wipe for this.

steps.headline: Reassemble the fan.
steps.description: Once both pieces of the fan are dust-free and completely dry, use a clockwise motion to reattach the top portion to the rest of the fan. It may help to use one hand to secure the fan in place while using your other hand to reattach the circular piece. If you are uncertain of how to reassemble your fan, double check the instructions that came with the fan when you purchased it.

text: Cleaning the Outside of the Fan Unplug the fan. Before cleaning your Dyson fan, make sure to unplug it. This prevents any risk of injury, and allows you to clean the fan thoroughly. Wipe the inside of the fan with a moist cloth. Dyson fans do not have blades, which makes the cleaning process a lot easier. Use a moist cloth to wipe inside the circular surface of the fan in long, swift motions. This process probably won’t take you more than 30 seconds. Use a wipe to clean the outermost surface of the fan. In addition to the fan’s inner portion, you should also clean the outside of the fan. You can use a wet paper towel or for this part of the cleaning process. Baby wipes also work for this part of the process. Attach a tube or brush extension to your vacuum. Find the attachment tube on your vacuum that allows you to clean smaller areas. Depending on your vacuum, you may have different kinds of  attachments. Add a long, thin tube or the brush attachment to your vacuum before continuing. If you don’t think you have the right vacuum attachment, consider purchasing one from an online marketplace (i.e, Amazon, eBay). Locate the back vents by searching for circular grooves. The location of the back vents may differ depending on your fan model. You can easily identify these vents by finding rows of circular grooves in a square pattern towards the bottom of your Dyson fan. Vacuum the back vent of the fan. Turn on the vacuum and hold the tube or brush extension tightly in one hand. Using careful and methodical movements, clear the dust from the back vent of your Dyson fan. Ideally, you do not want to see any dust particles once you have finished vacuuming. If you don’t have a vacuum or vacuum extension, feel free to use a can of compressed air. You can purchase this at most office supply stores. Brush off any remaining dust with a paper towel. Once you have finished vacuuming the back vents of the Dyson fan, examine the surface for any lingering dust or dirt. Using a dry paper towel or cloth, remove any excess dust with long, quick movements. Repeat this process if you still see a significant amount of dust. Wiping out the Inside of the Fan Twist off the top part of the fan. Use one hand to hold the bottom portion of the fan in place, and use your other hand to twist off the top, circular portion. Twist in a counter-clockwise motion when working to separate the two pieces of the Dyson fan. Don’t be discouraged if you’re unable to remove the top part. Check your fan’s user manual for more specific instructions on how to disassemble it. There should be a visible line that separates the rounded portion of the fan from the rest of the machine. Remove any dust from inside the fan with a wipe. While a Dyson fan does not have blades, there is a mechanical portion visible inside the fan after you’ve separated the two pieces. Use quick, delicate motions to lightly clean this inner portion with a damp cloth. You can use a can of compressed air instead of a damp cloth. Clean out the top part of the fan with a moist wipe. Using both hands, hold the circular portion upright so that you can examine the inside for dust. Depending on how much dust you find, use a damp cloth to clean and remove any dirt particles from inside the fan. Use small, careful motions during the cleaning process when wiping any rounded edges of the inner fan. You can also use a baby wipe for this. Reassemble the fan. Once both pieces of the fan are dust-free and completely dry, use a clockwise motion to reattach the top portion to the rest of the fan. It may help to use one hand to secure the fan in place while using your other hand to reattach the circular piece. If you are uncertain of how to reassemble your fan, double check the instructions that came with the fan when you purchased it.

Before cleaning your Dyson fan, make sure to unplug it.
This prevents any risk of injury, and allows you to clean the fan thoroughly.
Wipe the inside of the fan with a moist cloth.
Dyson fans do not have blades, which makes the cleaning process a lot easier.
Use a moist cloth to wipe inside the circular surface of the fan in long, swift motions.
This process probably won’t take you more than 30 seconds.
Use a wipe to clean the outermost surface of the fan.
In addition to the fan’s inner portion, you should also clean the outside of the fan.
You can use a wet paper towel or for this part of the cleaning process.
Baby wipes also work for this part of the process.
Attach a tube or brush extension to your vacuum.
Find the attachment tube on your vacuum that allows you to clean smaller areas.
Depending on your vacuum, you may have different kinds of  attachments.
Add a long, thin tube or the brush attachment to your vacuum before continuing.
If you don’t think you have the right vacuum attachment, consider purchasing one from an online marketplace (i.e, Amazon, eBay).
Locate the back vents by searching for circular grooves.
The location of the back vents may differ depending on your fan model.
You can easily identify these vents by finding rows of circular grooves in a square pattern towards the bottom of your Dyson fan.
Vacuum the back vent of the fan.
Turn on the vacuum and hold the tube or brush extension tightly in one hand.
Using careful and methodical movements, clear the dust from the back vent of your Dyson fan.
Ideally, you do not want to see any dust particles once you have finished vacuuming.
If you don’t have a vacuum or vacuum extension, feel free to use a can of compressed air.
You can purchase this at most office supply stores.
Brush off any remaining dust with a paper towel.
Once you have finished vacuuming the back vents of the Dyson fan, examine the surface for any lingering dust or dirt.
Using a dry paper towel or cloth, remove any excess dust with long, quick movements.
Repeat this process if you still see a significant amount of dust.
Wiping out the Inside of the Fan Twist off the top part of the fan.
Use one hand to hold the bottom portion of the fan in place, and use your other hand to twist off the top, circular portion.
Twist in a counter-clockwise motion when working to separate the two pieces of the Dyson fan.
Don’t be discouraged if you’re unable to remove the top part.
Check your fan’s user manual for more specific instructions on how to disassemble it.
There should be a visible line that separates the rounded portion of the fan from the rest of the machine.
Remove any dust from inside the fan with a wipe.
While a Dyson fan does not have blades, there is a mechanical portion visible inside the fan after you’ve separated the two pieces.
Use quick, delicate motions to lightly clean this inner portion with a damp cloth.
You can use a can of compressed air instead of a damp cloth.
Clean out the top part of the fan with a moist wipe.
Using both hands, hold the circular portion upright so that you can examine the inside for dust.
Depending on how much dust you find, use a damp cloth to clean and remove any dirt particles from inside the fan.
Use small, careful motions during the cleaning process when wiping any rounded edges of the inner fan.
You can also use a baby wipe for this.
Reassemble the fan.
Once both pieces of the fan are dust-free and completely dry, use a clockwise motion to reattach the top portion to the rest of the fan.
It may help to use one hand to secure the fan in place while using your other hand to reattach the circular piece.
If you are uncertain of how to reassemble your fan, double check the instructions that came with the fan when you purchased it.
